factoid: Pierre had not managed to choose a career for himself in Petersburg.
Pierre had been expelled from Petersburg for riotous conduct.
Pierre was sent to Moscow after expulsion.
The story told about Pierre at Count Rostóv’s was true.
Pierre had taken part in tying a policeman to a bear.
Pierre had been in Moscow for some days.
Pierre was staying at his father's house in Moscow.
Pierre expected that the story of his escapade would be known in Moscow.
Pierre expected that the ladies about his father would have used the story to turn the count against him.
Pierre went to his father's part of the house on the day of his arrival.
The drawing room is where the princesses spend most of their time.
Pierre greeted the ladies in the drawing room.
Two of the ladies were sitting at embroidery frames.
A third lady was reading aloud.
The eldest lady was reading and had met Anna Mikháylovna.
The two younger ladies were embroidering.
The two younger ladies were rosy and pretty.
One of the younger ladies had a little mole on her lip.
The mole made her much prettier.
Pierre was received as if Pierre were a corpse or a leper.
The eldest princess paused in her reading.
The eldest princess silently stared at Pierre with frightened eyes.
The second princess assumed precisely the same expression.
The youngest princess had a mole on her lip and was cheerful and lively.
The youngest princess bent over her embroidery frame to hide a smile probably evoked by the amusing scene she foresaw.
The youngest princess drew her wool down through the canvas.
The youngest princess could scarcely refrain from laughing.
The youngest princess stooped as if trying to make out the pattern.
Pierre said "How do you do, cousin?"
Pierre asked "You don't recognize me?"
The eldest princess replied "I recognize you only too well, too well."
Pierre asked "How is the count? Can I see him?"
The eldest princess said "The count is suffering physically and mentally."
The eldest princess said "You have done your best to increase his mental sufferings."
Pierre asked again "Can I see the count?"
The eldest princess said "If you wish to kill him, to kill him outright, you can see him."
The eldest princess said "Olga, go and see whether Uncle’s beef tea is ready—it is almost time."
The eldest princess indicated that Pierre was only busy causing annoyance.
Olga went out.
Pierre stood looking at the sisters.
Pierre bowed.
Pierre said "Then I will go to my rooms. You will let me know when I can see him."
Pierre left the room.
The sister with the mole laughed.
Prince Vasíli arrived the next day.
Prince Vasíli settled in the count’s house.
Prince Vasíli sent for Pierre.
Prince Vasíli said "My dear fellow, if you are going to behave here as you did in Petersburg, you will end very badly."
Prince Vasíli said "The count is very, very ill."
Prince Vasíli said "You must not see him at all."
Since then Pierre had not been disturbed.
Pierre spent all his time in his rooms upstairs.
When Borís appeared at Pierre's door.
Pierre paced up and down his room.
Pierre stopped occasionally at a corner to make menacing gestures at the wall.
Pierre made menacing gestures as if running a sword through an invisible foe.
Pierre glares savagely over his spectacles.
Pierre resumed his walk.
Pierre muttered indistinct words.
Pierre shrugged his shoulders.
Pierre gesticulated.
Pierre said "England is done for."
Pierre scowled.
Pierre pointed his finger at someone unseen.
Pierre said "Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the rights of man, is sentenced to…"
Pierre imagined himself to be Napoleon in person.
Pierre imagined he had just effected the dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured London.
Pierre saw a well-built and handsome young officer enter his room.
Pierre paused.
Pierre had left Moscow when Borís was a boy of fourteen.
Pierre had quite forgotten Borís.
Pierre took Borís by the hand with a friendly smile.
Borís asked "Do you remember me?" quietly with a pleasant smile.
Borís said "I have come with my mother to see the count, but it seems he is not well."
Pierre answered "Yes, it seems he is ill. People are always disturbing him."
Pierre was trying to remember who Borís was.
Borís felt that Pierre did not recognize him.
Borís did not consider it necessary to introduce himself.
Borís looked Pierre straight in the face without embarrassment.
Borís said "Count Rostóv asks you to come to dinner today."
The pause made Pierre feel uncomfortable.
